content:
- 14 -
衛生福利部民國107年7月20日 衛部秘字第1072161286號通知單註銷密等
CO-ORDINATION OF THE ACTIVITIES OF THE INTERNATIONAL CENTRES
(b) GEOGRAPHICAL DISTRIBUTION OF CONTACTS WITH THE NATIONAL CENTRES
The International Salmonella and Escherichia Centre in Copenhagen theoretically holds a world-wide coverage in a sense that does not apply to the two International Shigella Centres, for the reason that the former is a single institution while there are two of the latter. Therefore the Copenhagen Centre is free to establish direct links in its salmonella work with National Salmonella Centres wherever these may be situated, while the two International Shigella Centres in Atlanta and London are obliged to distribute their direct contacts in such a way as to avoid overlapping.
As for escherichia studies, it is not recommended that National Escherichia Centres should at present be designated as such in any country. The International Salmonella and Escherichia Centre supplies escherichia material as well as salmonella material to all National Salmonella Centres, and is prepared to assist the escherichia work of any country in essentially the same way as it assists the country's salmonella work.
The International Shigella Centres in Atlanta and London came under WHO sponsorship in response to a recommendation of the International Association of Microbiological Societies which, as mentioned on page 3 above, made recommendations with regard to
Graphical as distribution. Although WHO should give careful consideration to these recommendations, it must be stressed that the actual decision rests entirely with the Member States themselves, each of which naturally has complete freedom of choice as to whether the link of its Shigella Centre should be with the Atlanta or with the London International Centre. In making its choice each Member State will, of course, be more or less influenced by considerations of convenience, or of long-standing arrangements that may happen already to exist between its National Centre (or national laboratories) and one or other of the International Centres. Due weight would also, no doubt, be given to the general desirability from the epidemiological point of view, that each Region, part of a Region, or group of neighbouring countries, should have its shigella or similar needs catered for by a single International Centre rather than by two, so that the epidemiological information within the Region can be more easily correlated.
86
國史饭 Academia Historica :selected: :selected:
